ProcedureÂ¶

In a (small) nutshell, ESD calculation in kids_ggl proceeds as follows. The text below is mostly extracted (and somewhat updated) from Dvornik et al. (2017).

Since KiDS-450, kids_ggl uses a single photometric redshift distribution, which in KiDS is calculated by re-weighting the combination of a large number of overlapping redshift surveys so it matches the lensing-weighted magnitude distribution of the lensed source sample; we refer to this approach as DIR photo-z, and the resulting probability disstribution is labelled \(n(z_s)\). With this, we calculate the critical surface density, \(\Sigma_\mathrm{c}\), for every lens-source pair, as

\[\Sigma_\mathrm{c,ls}^{-1} = \frac{4\pi G}{c^2} \int_0^\infty \mathrm{d}z_l\,p(z_l)\,D(z_l) \int_{z_l+\delta_z}^\infty \mathrm{d}z_s\,n(z_s)\,\frac{D(z_l,z_s)}{D(z_s)}\]

where \(\delta_z\) (referred to as z_epsilon in the configuration file) is necessary to remove unlensed objects with \(z_s>z_l\), which exist due to photo-z errors, and is set by default at 0.2 (see Dvornik et al. (2017)); and \(p(z_l)\) is the probability distribution for each lens, modelled as a Gaussian with a (optionally redshift-dependent) width that is adjustable through the lens_pz_sigma parameter in the configuration file. The lensing signal is then calculated as

\[\Delta\Sigma(R) = \left[\frac{\sum_\mathrm{ls}w_\mathrm{ls}\epsilon_\mathrm{t}(1/\Sigma_\mathrm{c,ls}^{-1})} {\sum_\mathrm{ls}w_\mathrm{ls}}\right] \,\frac1{1+\mu}\]

where \(\mu\) is the weighted average multiplicative bias correction, calibrated with tailored image simulations, that take into account all aspects of the selection of lensed sources in the KiDS analysis.
